title: Rek'Sai's release proves lore isn't dead

embed.description: So lately the popular opinion of League's lore is that it is either low quality or non-existent, both because of what fans have dubbed "The Great Ret-con", when Riot's lore department removed the Institute of War from the official narrative.

body:
It's pretty ironic that the first champion {{champion:421}}  who, by Riot's own admission, isn't so much a character as a beast, should bring greater depth to the lore.  "Scourge of the Desert", aside from the melodramatic name, is a nice story piece that expands on the world of Runeterra, something that the narrative department at Riot has been promising for some time.   In my blog post, I go into a more detailed explanation of how we can infer more information on Noxus and Shurima and generally, why reports of the lore department's demise have been greatly exaggerated.  

This could have been a simple and stereotypical monster teaser - but it wasn't.  It had a narrator who became an actual character, in the sense that he underwent development and, in my case at least,  got the reader to actually care about him.  "Care" might be a strong word, but over the course of the story I caught myself thinking it was too bad Aelon was going to get eaten (since until the last page, I was certain he was).  

The start of Aelon's change in perspective takes place before he even hears of, let alone sees, {{champion:421}} so it does little to directly tie into her launch and from a marketing standpoint is fairly superfluous.  That it's here anyways should serve as proof that, contrary to what we've been tempted to think, **Riot does care about its game's lore.  **

The writers have always said they don't want to just do an "info-dump" but to give us lore in an interesting way - if this is what they mean, I'm all for it.

replies.body: Of course Riot is passionate about their lore, they wouldn't tear down everything we know about runeterra if they weren't.
A really accurate statement, thanks for saying it man!

Lore isn't dead. Lore outside of events and champion releases, however, is kinda dead.

I mean, this story was great, don't get me wrong, and I'm glad the narrator didn't die because that'd be kinda cliche. But I really just want Riot to release some sort of story that isn't trying to sell me something.
Agreed. I hope they bring back some equivalent to the JoJ now that the champs are more out and about. Just little things the champs are up to or where they are, that kind of thing.
just because they are listed as friends,doesn't mean they are in a relationship....
I remember this fellow...yeah...best to ignore him/her/it.
Welcome back Xano
Xano, it's been too long < 3
Well we did also get the sion promo which was quite awesome and gave us insight about the time of J1 and even a bit about the black rose and swain(nothing concrete,but at least something)
They didn't need to retcon the IoW to bring lore like this ;)

The problem with the IoW is that no matter how compelling the backstory of a champion was, there was always the question of "so why did they join the League?" and the answer would define their character, leaving little room for stories outside the League in the wider world.  And I mentioned in the long form post that monster champions would have very little variation in their backstories, devolving into roughly the same conclusion every time.

Summoner used pokeball!  {{champion:56}} was caught!  

Summoner used net ball!  {{champion:121}} was caught! (While there's no statement that he was captured, this is probably how his lore would have ended if the IoW had still been a part of the narrative when he was released.)

And so on.  That's more than a little boring, I suspect.

>

*cracks fingers*

It has begun.

Yes, coming up with new reasons to join the League may get difficult, but so is explaining what keeps these people fighting. Will any of them complete their story arcs? Is it possible for them to progress beyond it? Now we have the problem of all of these stand-alone champions with little interaction with others. Rek'Sai is so far an example of this.

Who said interactions would be scarce? They all live on the same continent, most of them have the capacity to travel, there's plenty of possibility for interactions. And no, Rek'sai is not an example of this. Who in their right mind would associate with Rek'sai? Better yet, why would Rek'sai interact with ANYONE outside of tearing them apart and feeding the scraps to her kin?

> [{quoted}](name=Glescoron,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=1jGmKoYi,comment-id=0002000000010000,timestamp=2014-12-16T00:25:56.356+0000)
>
> Who said interactions would be scarce? They all live on the same continent, most of them have the capacity to travel, there's plenty of possibility for interactions. And no, Rek'sai is not an example of this. Who in their right mind would associate with Rek'sai? Better yet, why would Rek'sai interact with ANYONE outside of tearing them apart and feeding the scraps to her kin?

But why would they leave their lands to interact with them though? Yes, we're not giving Riot the chance to explore this, but they already had this with the League.

About Rek'sai, then what's the point of her existing as a champion? No one would interact with her, so where do you take her story?

Ashe, Tryndamere, Lissandra, Sejuani, Swain, Darius, Leblanc, Jarvan, Gangplank, Miss Fortune, Karma and Irelia all have significant positions of diplomacy, and that's not even including other soldiers who would get involved should war break out. Ezreal going to see Lux, Garen and Katarina conducting secret meetings, Vayne tracking Vladimir across the continent, Lucian leading a crusade against the Shadow Isles, Syndra making a move for power by raining orbs of magic down upon Ionia, forcing it to make a plea for assistance to Demacia. Piltover and Zaun engaging in a kind of scientific conference when something goes wrong with heimerdinger's invention, prompting them to call Cait and Vi in to investigate and discover a conspiracy against the summit. ANY number of these examples could happen AND more. These champions aren't shut-ins, most of them interact with Valoran on a daily basis some way or another. 

And Rek'sai's point is the same as Cho'gath's. Massive, nebulous beasts of the void meant to be big scary buggaboos. Not every character needs complex motivations, some just need to be monsters. And dare I say, some just need to be fun champs to play.

Cho'Gath was designed around the League to basically be a prisoner. We don't know what his lore will be now. I'm not sure how giving a creature a reason to fight is a complex motivation. Rammus and Amumu existed before the retcon, and their reasons weren't complicated. You can be a fun champion and have a story. These aren't exclusive.

No, when they were designing cho'gath they didn't write "prisoner" in the middle of a paper and just go from there. Cho'gath was designed to be a monster, a beast of the void that we knew almost nothing about that could pose some threat to our world. The fact that he was a prisoner isn't so much his core design point than it is their excuse for having him fight in the league. 

Which brings me to a point in the retcon's faovr. We don't NEED excuses for the champs to fight anymore.

Why would Zac join the league exactly, for example? 

Think about it, he's implied to be a kind of superhero, wanting to help the innocent and the weak in their times of need like his parents taught him. Why would he get involved in political struggles? It would make more sense for him to go around the land just doing good for people he came across, trying to help in little ways. Politics is not the place for anyone looking to defend the weak, these battles were fought for land grabs and petty disputes between nations, there are no innocents in (most) of these large scale conflicts.

Now, without the need for these excuses, he can do what makes more sense for his character. Help anyone he comes across in danger. 

But I apologize, I got way off topic. To sort of sum up my point about Rek'sai, her design is the same as Cho'gath's. They're both these massive, terrifying monsters meant to act as a kind of hint at what the void has in store, to be really cool champs and to just generally eat and kill everything in their path.
Cho'Gath was designed around the Institute to manipulate and corrupt it. Though yes, the summoners were *entirely* convinced they held him prisoner.

No no no, the lazy thing to do would be to keep the IoW as it was and just never change or evolve the concept. What they're doing could be right or wrong, depending on how you look at it, but it's been A LOT of work to get the retcon through and deal with all the backlash. Like it or not, this is NOT lazy.

Exactly!  If they didn't care about lore, they wouldn't try to change and develop it.  Whatever one's feelings on their actions, the fact remains they are still taking said actions.  

Though I'm not sure if he was being sarcastic or not, Shinijumanjiman's comment fits here: "Of course Riot is passionate about their lore, they wouldn't tear down everything we know about runeterra if they weren't."

Ok then, stupid, not lazy.

"One can interpret"
At the same time i get what you're saying, but they are only releasing lore bits on champion release. The same as the last couple of champions.

Also at the same time, they havent release any actual lore of runterra of the city-states, due to a tech issue. But if that was true, why did they release that story about rek'sai? They shouldn't have been able to do so because of this "tech issue." 
The way i see that story of Aelon, is marketing.

Release lore of a new champion in order to get them to buy the champion, and not release what lore fans are truly looking for; Which is lore of Runeterra.
The lore is still dead because we still have no idea what's going on in the new Runeterra. And the fact that none of the Narrative even revealed themselves to answer any questions of Rek'Sai's lore.

That infamous tech issue was actually on that same page for that Noxian Cartographer. I'm sure thats the same way Narrative want to release stories. Which still makes me think Narrative is lying about this tech issue

We all have good reason to be suspicious but if it was pure marketing, there are so many things they would have left out and replaced them with to better promote the champion.  In my blog post I talk about how we're getting some lore of the places in Runeterra - Rek'Sai isn't even mentioned until the last few pages.  If marketing was their only goal with this, they would have made your standard "oh my god it's coming to eat us!" story from the point of view of a caravan like we saw in the teaser video.  Hell, the short story they release for her lore page will probably be something along these lines.  

I'm not saying this is an answer to all grievances, just that it's a start.
